cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
where would the group bacteroids likely be found
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
Bacteroids are a type of bacteria that are commonly found in the human gut, particularly in the intestines. They play a crucial role in the digestion of complex carbohydrates and the fermentation of dietary fibers. Bacteroids are part of the normal gut microbiota and contribute to the overall health of the digestive system. They thrive in anaerobic (low-oxygen) environments, which are typical of the intestinal tract. 

Given this information, it is reasonable to conclude that the group Bacteroids would likely be found in the intestines of humans and other animals that have a similar digestive system.

Answer:
The group Bacteroids would likely be found in the intestines of humans and other animals.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
where would the group bacteroids likely be found
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['Bacteroidetes are not limited to gut microbiota, they colonize a variety of habitats on Earth. For example, "Bacteroidetes", together with "Proteobacteria, Firmicutes" and "Actinobacteria", are also among the most abundant bacterial groups in rhizosphere. They have been detected in soil samples from various locations, including cultivated fields, greenhouse soils and unexploited areas. "Bacteroidetes" also inhabit freshwater lakes, rivers, as well as oceans. They are increasingly recognized as an important compartment of the bacterioplankton in marine environments, especially in pelagic oceans. Halophilic "Bacteroidetes" genus "Salinibacter" inhabit hypersaline environments such as salt-saturated brines in hypersaline lakes. "Salinibacter"\xa0 shares many properties with halophilic "Archaea" such as "Halobacterium" and "Haloquadratum" that inhabit the same environments. Phenotypically, "Salinibacter" is remarkably similar to "Halobacterium" and therefore for a long time remained unidentified.\n', 'Lacertoids have a wide geographic distribution. The Lacertidae are found throughout Europe and Asia, with a major radiation endemic to Africa. The Teiidae are diverse in South America, but some members of the group occur in southern North America as well. The Amphisbaenia are especially widespread, occurring in North America, Europe, Africa, South America, and the Caribbean. The origins of the group are unclear. The oldest definitive lacertoid is the amphisbaenian "Plesiorhineura", from the early Paleocene of North America. Given that it resembles modern worm lizards, the lacertoids most likely appeared and diversified in the Cretaceous.\n', 'The roseobacter clade is mostly found in the marine environment. The various species of roseobacter each have their own ecological niche. Several isolates have been captured from a vast number of ecosystems in coastal areas and open oceans. Roseobacters are a significant part of bacterial communities connected to phytoplankton, macroalgae, and several marine animals. Different lifestyles such as mutualistic and pathogenic have been proposed. Members of the clade are spread all over temperate and polar oceans, and are also considerable in sea ice ecosystems. They are suggested to be extensive within coastal sediments, deep pelagic ocean, and deep sea sediments. The roseobacter clade has immense diversity of metabolic proficiency and regulatory circuits, which can be credited to their prosperity in a vast number of marine ecosystems.\n', 'Fossils of the Danubitoidea have been found in the Triassic of Afghanistan, Russia, China, Papua New Guinea; Italy, Switzerland, Hungary; British Columbia, Yukon, Nunavut; Idaho, Nevada, and California.\n', 'Coleophora dubiella is a moth of the family Coleophoridae. It is found in Algeria, Libya, Morocco, Tunisia, Spain, France, southern Russia and Turkey.\n', 'were ultimately the ancestors of ammonoids and coleoids, and had appeared by the Floian. It is widely held that the Bactritida, a Silurian–Triassic group of orthocones, are paraphyletic to the coleoids and ammonoids – that is, the latter groups arose from within the Bactritida. An increase in the diversity of the coleoids and ammonoids is observed around the start of the Devonian period, and corresponds with a profound increase in fish diversity. This could represent the origin of the two derived groups.\n', 'In 2010, there was a discovery of two species that belong to this group of tapeworms to have infected bivalve mollusks in South Carolina. Lab samples were taken from this event in 200 clams which were measured and necropsied. Following the test, two species of tapeworm plerocercoids ("Duplicibothrium" spp) and merocercoids ("Rhodobothrium" spp) were observed. The plerocercoids occupied the digestive gland ducts and merocercoids were found beneath the mantle of the "Molinia lateralis", the clams from S. Carolina.\n', 'BULLET::::- Mellor, R.B.: Bacteroids in the Rhizobium-legume symbiosis inhabit a plant internal lytic compartment: Implications for other microbial endosymbioses. J Exp. Bot., 40, 831-839 (1989)\n', 'Eudendrium racemosum is a marine species of cnidaria, a hydroid (Hydrozoa) in the family Eudendriidae. It was described by Cavolini in 1785. Hydroids are one of the most abundant organisms in hard-substratum benthic communities, more specifically in temperate seas, such as the Mediterranean. Similar to most modular organisms, they have high growth rates. In fact, "E racemosum" has been frequently found in northeastern Spain, specifically in Medes Islands, showing a maximum population density in summer with a minimal density during the winter (this is when it typically exists as dormant stolon). Their rapid growth coupled with their ability to store the necessary material to survive the winter is due to their efficient feeding and digestive methods.\n', 'Members of the Gammaproteobacteria and Flaviobacteria classes were also shown to be abundant within the ice matrix, and thus to be adapted to the sea ice conditions. Genera of the Gammaproteobacteria class found in the Ross Sea and around the Antarctic waters include Colwellia, Marionomonas, Pseudoalteromonas and Psychrobacter. The orders Chlamydiales and Verrucomicrobiales were also found in the sea ice microbial assemblage of these locations. The predominance of Gammaproteobacteria in sea ice around the globe have been reported by many studies. A large proportion of the identified SIMCO in these studies were shown to belong to phylotypes associated with heterotrophic taxa\n']

which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

The first passage specifically discusses the habitats of Bacteroidetes, while the other passages do not provide relevant information about this group. Here’s a breakdown of the relevant content and its role in understanding the question:

### Extracted Content:
1. **Habitat Diversity**: 
   - "Bacteroidetes are not limited to gut microbiota, they colonize a variety of habitats on Earth."
   - "They have been detected in soil samples from various locations, including cultivated fields, greenhouse soils and unexploited areas."
   - "Bacteroidetes also inhabit freshwater lakes, rivers, as well as oceans."
   - "They are increasingly recognized as an important compartment of the bacterioplankton in marine environments, especially in pelagic oceans."
   - "Halophilic Bacteroidetes genus Salinibacter inhabit hypersaline environments such as salt-saturated brines in hypersaline lakes."

### Analysis of the Role of This Content:
- **Ecological Versatility**: The information highlights the ecological versatility of Bacteroidetes, indicating that they are not restricted to a single environment (like the gut) but are found in diverse habitats including soil, freshwater, and marine environments. This versatility is crucial for understanding their ecological roles and interactions in various ecosystems.
  
- **Soil and Aquatic Environments**: The mention of Bacteroidetes in soil and aquatic environments suggests their importance in nutrient cycling and their role in the microbiota of these ecosystems. This knowledge can help in understanding their contributions to soil health and aquatic ecosystems.

- **Halophilic Adaptations**: The reference to the genus Salinibacter, which thrives in hypersaline environments, illustrates the adaptability of Bacteroidetes to extreme conditions. This is important for recognizing their ecological significance in specialized environments.

- **Bacterioplankton**: The identification of Bacteroidetes as a significant component of bacterioplankton in marine environments emphasizes their role in oceanic ecosystems, particularly in nutrient cycling and interactions with phytoplankton.

### Conclusion:
The extracted content provides a comprehensive overview of the habitats where Bacteroidetes can be found, emphasizing their ecological diversity and significance. This background knowledge is essential for answering the question about the likely locations of Bacteroidetes, as it informs us that they can be found in a variety of environments beyond the gut, including soils, freshwater, and marine ecosystems. Understanding these habitats allows for a better grasp of their ecological roles and interactions within those environments.

Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:
Bacteroids, or more accurately, Bacteroidetes, are a diverse group of bacteria that are commonly associated with various environments. While they are well-known for their presence in the human gut, where they play a vital role in the digestion of complex carbohydrates and the fermentation of dietary fibers, their ecological presence extends far beyond this singular habitat.

1. **Habitat Diversity**: Bacteroidetes are not limited to the gut microbiota; they colonize a variety of habitats on Earth. They have been detected in soil samples from cultivated fields, greenhouse soils, and unexploited areas, indicating their role in terrestrial ecosystems.

2. **Aquatic Environments**: Bacteroidetes are also found in freshwater lakes, rivers, and oceans. They are increasingly recognized as an important component of the bacterioplankton in marine environments, particularly in pelagic oceans. This suggests their involvement in aquatic nutrient cycling and interactions with other marine organisms.

3. **Halophilic Adaptations**: Certain genera within Bacteroidetes, such as Salinibacter, thrive in hypersaline environments, such as salt-saturated brines in hypersaline lakes. This adaptability to extreme conditions highlights their ecological versatility.

4. **Ecological Roles**: The presence of Bacteroidetes in various environments indicates their significant roles in nutrient cycling, soil health, and aquatic ecosystems. Their ability to thrive in anaerobic conditions is particularly relevant for their function in the gut, but it also suggests they can adapt to other low-oxygen environments.

### Conclusion:
Given the ecological versatility of Bacteroidetes, it is reasonable to conclude that they can be found in a variety of habitats, including the intestines of humans and other animals, as well as in soils, freshwater, and marine environments. This broader understanding of their habitats enhances the original inference about their presence in the intestines.

### Answer:
The group Bacteroids (Bacteroidetes) would likely be found in the intestines of humans and other animals, as well as in diverse environments such as soils, freshwater lakes, rivers, and marine ecosystems. They are adaptable and can thrive in various habitats, including extreme conditions like hypersaline environments.

     - **Hypersaline Environments**: Certain genera, such as Salinibacter, thrive in extreme saline conditions, like salt-saturated brines in hypersaline lakes.

2. **Ecological Roles**:
   - Bacteroidetes play crucial roles in nutrient cycling and organic matter decomposition in various ecosystems. Their presence in diverse habitats indicates their adaptability and ecological significance.

3. **Comparison with Other Bacteria**:
   - The passages also mention other bacterial groups (e.g., Proteobacteria, Firmicutes, Actinobacteria) that coexist with Bacteroidetes in similar environments, highlighting the complex interactions within microbial communities.

### Conclusion:

The passages provide foundational knowledge about the ecological niches occupied by Bacteroidetes, particularly Bacteroids, and their roles in various environments. This understanding is essential for comprehending the broader implications of microbial diversity and function in ecosystems. By recognizing the adaptability and ecological significance of Bacteroidetes, one can appreciate their importance in both natural and anthropogenic contexts. Bacteroids are indeed a type of bacteria primarily recognized for their role in the human gut microbiota, where they contribute significantly to the digestion of complex carbohydrates and the fermentation of dietary fibers. However, the retrieved passages reveal that the ecological distribution of Bacteroidetes, the group to which Bacteroids belong, extends far beyond the human gut.

1. **Diverse Habitats**: 
   - Bacteroidetes are found in various environments, including:
     - **Soil**: They are prevalent in the rhizosphere, which is the region of soil influenced by plant roots. This indicates their role in soil health and plant growth.
     - **Aquatic Systems**: They inhabit freshwater lakes, rivers, and oceans, contributing to bacterioplankton communities. This highlights their importance in aquatic ecosystems, where they may play roles in nutrient cycling and organic matter decomposition.
     - **Extreme Environments**: Certain genera, such as Salinibacter, thrive in hypersaline conditions, showcasing their adaptability to extreme environments.

2. **Ecological Importance**: 
   - Bacteroidetes are crucial for nutrient cycling and organic matter decomposition across various ecosystems. Their presence in diverse habitats suggests they have evolved to perform essential ecological functions, which can impact soil fertility, water quality, and overall ecosystem health.

3. **Microbial Interactions**: 
   - The coexistence of Bacteroidetes with other bacterial groups (e.g., Proteobacteria, Firmicutes, Actinobacteria) in similar environments indicates complex interactions within microbial communities. Understanding these interactions can provide insights into microbial ecology and the dynamics of ecosystem functioning.

4. **Adaptation and Evolution**: 
   - The ability of Bacteroidetes to thrive in a wide range of environments reflects their evolutionary adaptations. This adaptability can inform research on microbial evolution and the mechanisms that allow bacteria to survive in diverse and sometimes extreme conditions.

### Conclusion:
The enhanced understanding of Bacteroids emphasizes that while they are commonly found in the intestines of humans and other animals, they also inhabit a variety of other environments, including soil and aquatic ecosystems. This broader perspective highlights their ecological significance and adaptability.

### Answer:
The group Bacteroids would likely be found in the intestines of humans and other animals, as well as in diverse environments such as soil (particularly in the rhizosphere), freshwater lakes, rivers, and oceans. They are also present in extreme habitats like hypersaline environments, showcasing their adaptability and ecological importance across various ecosystems.

', 'Eudendrium racemosum is a marine species of cnidaria, a hydroid (Hydrozoa) in the family Eudendriidae. It was described by Cavolini in 1785. Hydroids are one of the most abundant organisms in hard-substratum benthic communities, more specifically in temperate seas, such as the Mediterranean. Similar to most modular organisms, they have high growth rates. In fact, "E racemosum" has been frequently found in northeastern Spain, specifically in Medes Islands, showing a maximum population density in summer with a minimal density during the winter (this is when it typically exists as dormant stolon). Their rapid growth coupled with their ability to store the necessary material to survive the winter is due to their efficient feeding and digestive methods.
', 'Members of the Gammaproteobacteria and Flaviobacteria classes were also shown to be abundant within the ice matrix, and thus to be adapted to the sea ice conditions. Genera of the Gammaproteobacteria class found in the Ross Sea and around the Antarctic waters include Colwellia, Marionomonas, Pseudoalteromonas and Psychrobacter. The orders Chlamydiales and Verrucomicrobiales were also found in the sea ice microbial assemblage of these locations. The predominance of Gammaproteobacteria in sea ice around the globe have been reported by many studies. A large proportion of the identified SIMCO in these studies were shown to belong to phylotypes associated with heterotrophic taxa
']

Task Description:
Please extract content from these passages that can help enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities.
consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate relevant information from the provided passages regarding the habitats of Bacteroidetes. Here’s a summary of the key points:

### Extracted Information:
1. **Diverse Habitats**: Bacteroidetes are not restricted to gut microbiota; they colonize various habitats on Earth, including:
   - **Soil**: Found in cultivated fields, greenhouse soils, and unexploited areas.
   - **Freshwater**: Detected in lakes and rivers.
   - **Marine Environments**: Significant presence in oceans, particularly as part of bacterioplankton in pelagic zones.
   - **Hypersaline Environments**: Certain genera, like Salinibacter, thrive in salt-saturated brines of hypersaline lakes.

2. **Ecological Roles**: Bacteroidetes play important roles in different ecosystems, contributing to nutrient cycling and interactions with other organisms.

3. **Adaptability**: The ability of Bacteroidetes to inhabit diverse environments suggests a high level of adaptability and metabolic diversity, which can influence their ecological roles.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:
1. **Understanding Ecosystem Dynamics**: By recognizing that Bacteroidetes inhabit various environments, the model can better infer how changes in one habitat (e.g., pollution in freshwater) might affect their populations and, consequently, the broader ecosystem. This understanding can lead to more accurate predictions about ecological outcomes.

2. **Interconnectedness of Habitats**: The information about Bacteroidetes being present in both terrestrial and aquatic environments allows the model to reason about the interconnectedness of ecosystems. For instance, it can infer how soil health (where Bacteroidetes are present) can impact water quality in nearby lakes and rivers.

3. **Adaptation and Evolution**: The adaptability of Bacteroidetes to extreme environments (like hypersaline conditions) can inform the model about evolutionary processes and the potential for species to survive in changing climates. This understanding can enhance the model's ability to predict how microbial communities might shift in response to environmental stressors.

4. **Microbial Interactions**: The role of Bacteroidetes in nutrient cycling and their interactions with other organisms (e.g., in symbiotic relationships) can help the model infer the consequences of microbial community changes on plant health and soil fertility.

### Conclusion:
The extracted information about Bacteroidetes enhances the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities by providing a framework to understand ecological interactions, adaptability, and the implications of environmental changes. This knowledge allows for more nuanced predictions and insights into microbial ecology and its broader impacts on ecosystems.

where would the group bacteroids likely be found

Bacteroids are a type of bacteria that are commonly found in the human gut, particularly in the intestines. They thrive in anaerobic (low-oxygen) environments, which are typical of the intestinal tract. 

Given this information, it is reasonable to conclude that the group Bacteroids would likely be found in the intestines of humans and other animals that have a similar digestive system.

Answer:
The group Bacteroids would likely be found in the intestines of humans and other animals.

Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
where would the group bacteroids likely be found

Passages:
['Bacteroidetes are not limited to gut microbiota, they colonize a variety of habitats on Earth. For example, "Bacteroidetes", together with "Proteobacteria, Firmicutes" and "Actinobacteria", are also among the most abundant bacterial groups in rhizosphere. They have been detected in soil samples from various locations, including cultivated fields, greenhouse soils and unexploited areas. "Bacteroidetes" also inhabit freshwater lakes, rivers, as well as oceans. They are increasingly recognized as an important compartment of the bacterioplankton in marine environments, especially in pelagic oceans. Halophilic "Bacteroidetes" genus "Salinibacter" inhabit hypersaline environments such as salt-saturated brines in hypersaline lakes. "Salinibacter"\xa0 shares many properties with halophilic "Archaea" such as "Halobacterium" and "Haloquadratum" that inhabit the same environments. Phenotypically, "Salinibacter" is remarkably similar to "Halobacterium" and therefore for a long time remained unidentified.\n', 'Lacertoids have a wide geographic distribution. The Lacertidae are found throughout Europe and Asia, with a major radiation endemic to Africa. The Teiidae are diverse in South America, but some members of the group occur in southern North America as well. The Amphisbaenia are especially widespread, occurring in North America, Europe, Africa, South America, and the Caribbean. The origins of the group are unclear. The oldest definitive lacertoid is the amphisbaenian "Plesiorhineura", from the early Paleocene of North America. Given that it resembles modern worm lizards, the lacertoids most likely appeared and diversified in the Cretaceous.\n', 'The roseobacter clade is mostly found in the marine environment. The various species of roseobacter each have their own ecological niche. Several isolates have been captured from a vast number of ecosystems in coastal areas and open oceans. Roseobacters are a significant part of bacterial communities connected to phytoplankton, macroalgae, and several marine animals. Different lifestyles such as mutualistic and pathogenic have been proposed. Members of the clade are spread all over temperate and polar oceans, and are also considerable in sea ice ecosystems. They are suggested to be extensive within coastal sediments, deep pelagic ocean, and deep sea sediments. The roseobacter clade has immense diversity of metabolic proficiency and regulatory circuits, which can be credited to their prosperity in a vast number of marine ecosystems.\n', 'Fossils of the Danubitoidea have been found in the Triassic of Afghanistan, Russia, China, Papua New Guinea; Italy, Switzerland, Hungary; British Columbia, Yukon, Nunavut; Idaho, Nevada, and California.\n', 'Coleophora dubiella is a moth of the family Coleophoridae. It is found in Algeria, Libya, Morocco, Tunisia, Spain, France, southern Russia and Turkey.\n', 'were ultimately the ancestors of ammonoids and coleoids, and had appeared by the Floian. It is widely held that the Bactritida, a Silurian–Triassic group of orthocones, are paraphyletic to the coleoids and ammonoids – that is, the latter groups arose from within the Bactritida. An increase in the diversity of the coleoids and ammonoids is observed around the start of the Devonian period, and corresponds with a profound increase in fish diversity. This could represent the origin of the two derived groups.\n', 'In 2010, there was a discovery of two species that belong to this group of tapeworms to have infected bivalve mollusks in South Carolina. Similar to most modular organisms, they have high growth rates. In fact, "E racemosum" has been frequently found in northeastern Spain, specifically in Medes Islands, showing a maximum population density in summer with a minimal density during the winter (this is when it typically exists as dormant stolon). Their rapid growth coupled with their ability to store the necessary material to survive the winter is due to their efficient feeding and digestive methods.\n', 'Members of the Gammaproteobacteria and Flaviobacteria classes were also shown to be abundant within the ice matrix, and thus to be adapted to the sea ice conditions. question_info.question: where would the group bacteroids likely be found
passages:
Bacteroidetes are not limited to gut microbiota, they colonize a variety of habitats on Earth. For example, "Bacteroidetes", together with "Proteobacteria, Firmicutes" and "Actinobacteria", are also among the most abundant bacterial groups in rhizosphere. They have been detected in soil samples from various locations, including cultivated fields, greenhouse soils and unexploited areas. "Bacteroidetes" also inhabit freshwater lakes, rivers, as well as oceans. They are increasingly recognized as an important compartment of the bacterioplankton in marine environments, especially in pelagic oceans. Halophilic "Bacteroidetes" genus "Salinibacter" inhabit hypersaline environments such as salt-saturated brines in hypersaline lakes. "Salinibacter"  shares many properties with halophilic "Archaea" such as "Halobacterium" and "Haloquadratum" that inhabit the same environments. Phenotypically, "Salinibacter" is remarkably similar to "Halobacterium" and therefore for a long time remained unidentified.
Lacertoids have a wide geographic distribution. The Lacertidae are found throughout Europe and Asia, with a major radiation endemic to Africa. The Teiidae are diverse in South America, but some members of the group occur in southern North America as well. The Amphisbaenia are especially widespread, occurring in North America, Europe, Africa, South America, and the Caribbean. The origins of the group are unclear. The oldest definitive lacertoid is the amphisbaenian "Plesiorhineura", from the early Paleocene of North America. Given that it resembles modern worm lizards, the lacertoids most likely appeared and diversified in the Cretaceous.
The roseobacter clade is mostly found in the marine environment. The various species of roseobacter each have their own ecological niche. Several isolates have been captured from a vast number of ecosystems in coastal areas and open oceans. Roseobacters are a significant part of bacterial communities connected to phytoplankton, macroalgae, and several marine animals. Different lifestyles such as mutualistic and pathogenic have been proposed. Members of the clade are spread all over temperate and polar oceans, and are also considerable in sea ice ecosystems. They are suggested to be extensive within coastal sediments, deep pelagic ocean, and deep sea sediments. The roseobacter clade has immense diversity of metabolic proficiency and regulatory circuits, which can be credited to their prosperity in a vast number of marine ecosystems.
Fossils of the Danubitoidea have been found in the Triassic of Afghanistan, Russia, China, Papua New Guinea; Italy, Switzerland, Hungary; British Columbia, Yukon, Nunavut; Idaho, Nevada, and California.
Coleophora dubiella is a moth of the family Coleophoridae. It is found in Algeria, Libya, Morocco, Tunisia, Spain, France, southern Russia and Turkey.
were ultimately the ancestors of ammonoids and coleoids, and had appeared by the Floian. It is widely held that the Bactritida, a Silurian–Triassic group of orthocones, are paraphyletic to the coleoids and ammonoids – that is, the latter groups arose from within the Bactritida. An increase in the diversity of the coleoids and ammonoids is observed around the start of the Devonian period, and corresponds with a profound increase in fish diversity. This could represent the origin of the two derived groups.
In 2010, there was a discovery of two species that belong to this group of tapeworms to have infected bivalve mollusks in South Carolina. Lab samples were taken from this event in 200 clams which were measured and necropsied. Following the test, two species of tapeworm plerocercoids ("Duplicibothrium" spp) and merocercoids ("Rhodobothrium" spp) were observed. The plerocercoids occupied the digestive gland ducts and merocercoids were found beneath the mantle of the "Molinia lateralis", the clams from S. Carolina.
BULLET::::- Mellor, R.B.: Bacteroids in the Rhizobium-legume symbiosis inhabit a plant internal lytic compartment: Implications for other microbial endosymbioses. J Exp. Bot., 40, 831-839 (1989)
Eudendrium racemosum is a marine species of cnidaria, a hydroid (Hydrozoa) in the family Eudendriidae. It was described by Cavolini in 1785. Hydroids are one of the most abundant organisms in hard-substratum benthic communities, more specifically in temperate seas, such as the Mediterranean. Similar to most modular organisms, they have high growth rates. In fact, "E racemosum" has been frequently found in northeastern Spain, specifically in Medes Islands, showing a maximum population density in summer with a minimal density during the winter (this is when it typically exists as dormant stolon). Their rapid growth coupled with their ability to store the necessary material to survive the winter is due to their efficient feeding and digestive methods.
Members of the Gammaproteobacteria and Flaviobacteria classes were also shown to be abundant within the ice matrix, and thus to be adapted to the sea ice conditions. Genera of the Gammaproteobacteria class found in the Ross Sea and around the Antarctic waters include Colwellia, Marionomonas, Pseudoalteromonas and Psychrobacter. The orders Chlamydiales and Verrucomicrobiales were also found in the sea ice microbial assemblage of these locations. The predominance of Gammaproteobacteria in sea ice around the globe have been reported by many studies. A large proportion of the identified SIMCO in these studies were shown to belong to phylotypes associated with heterotrophic taxa
